title: Stocks Eke Out Gains on Trump's Latest Tariff Talk | Closing Bell

rawLines.text: And right now we are 2 minutes away from
the end of the trading day. Roma Bostic
alongside Scarlet Fu taking you through
to the closing bell with a global
simalcast. It starts now. Tim Senovic
joining us from the radio booth. Nora
Melinda in today for Carol Masser.
Welcome to our audiences across all of
our Bloomberg platforms including our
partnership with YouTube. Tim Senovic
green across the screen for most of the
major indices. But of course we have two
big catalysts coming up on the calendar
within the next 24 hours. I think you
would be referring to CPI and then the
kickoff of big bank earnings tomorrow.
Is that right?
That is correct.
Okay. Looks like we're reading the same
stuff. Roma Boston, that's always good
news when we're on the same page. Hey,
there's also the trade element here and
I think that's what people thought and
certainly kind of did dominate today's
trade even though we didn't see a big
variation between gains and losses. The
comments of about President Trump kind
of saying, okay, maybe not 30% for
Europe. they're were open to negotiating
given what happened over the weekend
might have given a little bit of a
relief to investors out there today.
I mean definitely some relief that we
are seeing here with all indexes ending
in the green as we were saying earlier
if you went to sleep on New Year's Day
and you woke up today lots happened in
between but if you look at the S&P 500
not much has changed.
Yeah. I go to Tim's point about you know
the trade tariffs uh and the threatened
tariffs uh not showing up in the price
action but showing up in activity
because volume is certainly down
compared to the 30-day average. Yeah, we
should point out of course I mean just I
think the earnings picture is really
going to be one that drives this market.
Not so much for the second quarter
results but obviously the commentary the
commentary that a lot of CEOs and CFOs
were unwilling to give the last goround.
This time around they might not have as

here on this Monday afternoon for most

Industrial Average looking like it's
going to close out the day higher by
more than 80 points or about 210 of 1%.
The S&P up just about 10 points on the
day. We'll call it about a tenth of a
percent as we wait for these numbers to
settle. The NASDAQ composite adding
about 3/10en of a percent. And the Russa
2000, that's your outperformer on the
day again up 15 points or about 7/10 of
All right, taking a look at how things
split up in terms of gainers and
decliners today. We did see more stocks
move higher in the S&P. 286 to the
upside, Scarlet 213 to the downside.
And that's reflected in the IMAP as
well. So, take a look at the 11 sectors
in the S&P 500. That big red slice that
you see there is tech. Uh, but it's only
down by two ten of 1%. The leading
decliners here are energy stocks as oil
prices sink and material stocks also
lower by 4/10en of 1%. Best performers,
communication services, financials
before the banks report earnings
tomorrow and real estate investment
trust.
All right, on the gainer side, a new
all-time high for Fastenal. The company
reported earnings earlier today. Shares
4% higher at the close. The company
reported net sales for the second
quarter that were up 8.6% over the same
period last year. It did meet the
average analyst estimate. We had Dan
Flores on the show, the company's CEO.
He said that his industrial customers
are starting to see business turnaround.
Here's what he said. Quote, "The knife
has stopped dropping." What he was
referring to is the trying to catch a
falling knife over the last few years
that really in the US has been
industrial production. I did ask him and
Norah asked him too about the impact of
tariffs and he said they tried to move
their supply chain back in 2018 during
this first round and they were able to
make some changes not necessarily
bringing anything back to the US just
not possible right now. Uh too early to
say for his customers though whether
this new tariff regime will prompt them
to move manufacturing back to the US.
It's just a reminder of how long it
takes to actually move your supply chain
back to the US. if they were talking
about this back in 2017 and, you know,
weren't able to to get very far.
Yeah. I mean, do you remember the move
back in 2017 and 2018 was to move
everything out of China and like go to
Vietnam or Indonesia or India? Well, now
it kind of doesn't matter where you are
if you're not in the United States
because all of those countries are
getting tariffed as well. Hey, did any
of you guys see Superman over the
weekend?
No. Was it good?
I didn't see it either. A lot of people
did see it though.
We look at you when we see Superman. I
was going to say,
wow, you guys, you guys are the best. Uh
Warner Brothers Discovery shares up more
than 2%. Uh this after the company did
say uh that they brought in at least
$115 million domestically. It did take
in $220 million worldwide. This
according to a statement from Warner
Brothers, excuse me, $125 million in

just the opening chapter in a 10-year
plan dinnerweave movies and TV shows
based on DC comic book characters such
as Batman and Wonder Woman. Would
haven't they done this before?
Yeah.
Okay. All right. I'm just
They've done this and so I mean I don't
know. Do you think DC is going to get it
right this time? I mean everyone's
saying okay you had a decent box office
domestically though though don't look at
the international numbers Tim was not as

could finally build off this and and
actually truly build up something that's
comparable to the Marvel universe. Look,
I don't know what it takes to have a
successful franchise. No question.
I don't either, but I like opinion.
But but we can we can look and see what
you know what what the Marvel universe
has done, right?
Peanut gallery speaks.
Yeah, exactly. I think James Gun knows a
little more than we do when it comes to
what makes a successful movie. Uh and
finally, I I do want to talk about Ken
View real quick. Up they finished the
day higher today by more than 2%. It's
the company behind Tylenol Neutrogena
Lististerine, formerly the consumer
healthcare division of J&J. The company
said that CEO Thiba Ming Mongol is going
to leave the company as it continues to
revamp. The board director Kirk Perry
will take over as interim CEO effective
immediately. They faced push from
activist investors for changes on how
the company is structured and run ever
since it was spun off from J&J just a
couple of years ago. Once again, Kenv
shares up by more than 2.2%. Nora,
well, a couple decliners that I'm
keeping an eye on right now. We had
Waters, uh, that is a life sciences
company about $18 billion in market cap.
It fell for double-digit losses when we
ended at the close today after saying
that it'll merge with Beckton
Dickinson's biosciences and diagnostic
solutions business in a reverse Morris
Trust transaction that's valued at about
17.5 billion. We had Jeffre analyst
saying that they expect the stock to
trade down due to the deal size and
variables added to a clean replacement
cycle story. But if you look at the
stock on a year-to- date basis down
about 18%. I know it's Monday, but I did
want to talk about an alcohol company.
I'm looking at Constellation Brands, and
we're seeing shares that also fell at
the close today after President Trump
declared a 30% tariff for Mexico and the
EU. Uh, which of course we know these
are key markets for those drink makers.
So, tariffs are really the story here.
But, uh, this is a 28 billion company.
They own Medela, Corona, a lot of the
names that we know here. But, shares are
down about 26% this year. So, not great
news here for the brand. Maybe people
are going to healthier alternatives.
We'll see.
I like the fact you picked an alcohol
company because you really truly are
filling Carol Masters.
Have to live up to it the best I can.
Also, Fluence Energy, that's uh an
energy per uh this is an energy company
and we saw energy is the worst
performing sector in the S&P 500 today
and this was one of the names that was
in the red. Missou cut the stock to
neutral from outperform. They're also
pointing toward this tariff impact and
additionally the Republican tax and
spending bills effects on the clean
energy sector. The company's about$ 1.4
billion dollars in market cap. But I'm
looking at the year-to- date as well
down 50%. Not looking good.
All right, let's get a quick check on
yields. Continue to see a steepening of
the curve. Treasuries overall falling
for a third straight day. That's pushing
yields higher, but two interesting
dynamics are playing out. One is
obviously that you're seeing much
greater moves in yields on the longer
end of the curve to the upside. But on
the short end of the curve, take a look
at that. A one basis point move, one and
a half if you want to be uh particular
on that two-year yield. And that has
been the narrow range that we've
actually seen on the shorter end of the
curve now for quite some time. In fact,
the past three sessions, we basically
had one basis point, one basis point,
and then three basis points. And then if
you keep going out, it really doesn't
get much wider than that. And I think it
is kind of telling uh Tim and Nora this
idea uh that maybe you have a market at
least in the Treasury market with a lot
of folks right now on the sidelines.
Okay. Well, we'll see what happens when
it comes to CPI. We'll see what happens
when it comes to the big banks reporting
earnings. In the meantime, I want to
talk a little bit about return to
office. Yeah, we're still talking about
that. It's back in the news this week
because Starbucks employees who work at
corporate headquarters are apparently
going to be required to come in 4 days a
week. This is a focus. Excuse me. Which
four?
I don't know.
Maybe they get to select the day that
they stay home.
Well, I know that there are some places
where they're like, "Okay, everybody has
to come in at least on like, you know,
Monday because that's like our inoff
day." And it ser look kind of looks like
not a lot of people go to work on
Friday. Just anecdotally speaking, at
least here in New York Subway. I don't
know.
Well, we're all here, right? We're in
person. But I think this is really
interesting for Starbucks. I mean, I was
just at Starbucks yesterday and I had a
nice refresher. I don't know if you guys
have had the refreshers, but fantastic.
And we're really seeing, you know,
Starbucks really just trying to do
better. They're trying to have a
turnaround story here. So, I guess they
need people in the office to do it.
Well, it starts with the culture
according to Brian Nickel, who's the CEO
of Starbucks. Um, you know, we're
keeping an eye, of course, on the tariff
story. And even though there's new
threats of tariffs, uh, and, uh,
companies still aren't able to say very
much, there is evidence that it is
affecting certain industries. The
world's largest swimming pool maker says
they will likely hike prices for a
second time this year because of Trump's
proposed tariffs. This is a Spanish
company, Fluidra, uh talking about this
and they said how much they can't say
right now really depends on what gets
announced about China in the coming
weeks.
Yeah, and this is kind of what I'm
really interested in for this particular
earning season. The idea as to whether
we're going to hear more companies, more
certainly more US companies start to
talk about the potential impact. We just
had Nadia Levelvel on the TV program a
little while ago and she was kind of
alluding to this idea that we've
collected in this country more than
hundred billion dollars in tariff
revenue but of course we know that comes
out of someone's pocket and at least for
right now we have not actually seen that
show up in some of these income
statements or in some of the inflation
data and I do wonder if that's about to
change
and that's why the guidance tomorrow and
throughout the rest of earning season is
going to be so important the commentary
that we hear although is there more
clarity that's you know about what the
actual policies At some point they have
to company executives just need to say
how they're moving forward even if they
don't have the clarity. Right.
Absolutely.
Okay. We'll wait.
What kind of swimming pool do you have
Scarlet?
Mine is massive.
All right. Party at Scarlet this
weekend. Thanks for the interview.
to it.

And right now, we are two minutes away from the end of the trading day. Romaine Bostick, alongside Scarlet Fu, taking you through to the Closing Bell with a global simulcast. It starts now. Tim Stenovec joining us from the radio booth. Norah Mulinda in today for Carol Masser. Welcome to our audiences across all of our Bloomberg platforms, including our partnership with YouTube. Tim Stenovec, green across the screen for most of the major indices. But of course, we have two big catalysts coming up on the calendar within the next 24 hours. I think you would be referring to CPI and then the kickoff of big bank earnings tomorrow. Is that right?

That is correct.

Okay. Looks like we're reading the same stuff. Romaine Bostick, that's always good news when we're on the same page. Hey, there's also the trade element here, and I think that's what people thought, and certainly kind of did dominate today's trade, even though we didn't see a big variation between gains and losses. The comments of about President Trump kind of saying, okay, maybe not 30% for Europe. They were open to negotiating, given what happened over the weekend, might have given a little bit of a relief to investors out there today.

I mean, definitely some relief that we are seeing here with all indexes ending in the green, as we were saying earlier. If you went to sleep on New Year's Day and you woke up today, lots happened in between, but if you look at the S&P 500, not much has changed.

Yeah. I go to Tim's point about, you know, the trade tariffs, uh, and the threatened tariffs, uh, not showing up in the price action, but showing up in activity because volume is certainly down compared to the 30-day average. Yeah, we should point out, of course, I mean, just I think the earnings picture is really going to be one that drives this market. Not so much for the second quarter results, but obviously the commentary, the commentary that a lot of CEOs and CFOs were unwilling to give the last go-round. This time around, they might not have as much coverage. Green across the screen here on this Monday afternoon for most of the major indices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average looking like it's going to close out the day higher by more than 80 points, or about 2/10 of 1%. The S&P up just about 10 points on the day. We'll call it about a tenth of a percent as we wait for these numbers to settle. The NASDAQ composite adding about 3/10 of a percent. And the Russia 2000, that's your outperformer on the day, again up 15 points, or about 7/10 of 1%.

All right, taking a look at how things split up in terms of gainers and decliners today. We did see more stocks move higher in the S&P, 286 to the upside, Scarlet, 213 to the downside. And that's reflected in the IMAP as well. So, take a look at the 11 sectors in the S&P 500. That big red slice that you see there is tech, uh, but it's only down by 2/10 of 1%. The leading decliners here are energy stocks as Oil prices sink and material stocks also lower by 4/10 of 1%. Best performers, communication services, financials before the banks report earnings tomorrow, and real estate investment trusts.

All right, on the gainer side, a new all-time high for Fastenal. The company reported earnings earlier today. Shares 4% higher at the close. The company reported net sales for the second quarter that were up 8.6% over the same period last year. It did meet the average analyst estimate. We had Dan Flores on the show, the company's CEO. He said that his industrial customers are starting to see business turnaround. Here's what he said. Quote, "The knife has stopped dropping." What he was referring to is the trying to catch a falling knife over the last few years that really in the US has been industrial production. I did ask him, and Norah asked him too, about the impact of tariffs, and he said they tried to move their supply chain back in 2018 during this first round, and they were able to make some changes, not necessarily bringing anything back to the US, just not possible right now. Uh, too early to say for his customers though whether this new tariff regime will prompt them to move manufacturing back to the US. It's just a reminder of how long it takes to actually move your supply chain back to the US. If they were talking about this back in 2017 and, you know, weren't able to get very far.

Yeah. I mean, do you remember the move back in 2017 and 2018 was to move everything out of China and like go to Vietnam or Indonesia or India? Well, now it kind of doesn't matter where you are if you're not in the United States because all of those countries are getting tariffed as well. Hey, did any of you guys see Superman over the weekend?

No. Was it good?

I didn't see it either. A lot of people did see it though.

We look at you when we see Superman. I was going to say,

wow, you guys, you guys are the best. Uh, Warner Brothers Discovery shares up more than 2%. Uh, this after the company did say, uh, that they brought in at least $115 million domestically. It did take in $220 million worldwide. This according to a statement from Warner Brothers, excuse me, $125 million in ticket sales in the US. So that did beat expectations of $115 million. This is just the opening chapter in a 10-year plan dinnerweave movies and TV shows based on DC comic book characters such as Batman and Wonder Woman. Wouldn't they have done this before?

Yeah.

Okay. All right. I'm just

They've done this, and so I mean, I don't know. Do you think DC is going to get it right this time? But this idea that maybe they could finally build off this and and actually truly build up something that's comparable to the Marvel universe. Look, I don't know what it takes to have a successful franchise. No question.

I don't either, but I like opinion.

But, but we can, we can look and see what, you know, what, what the Marvel universe has done, right?

Peanut gallery speaks.

Yeah, exactly. I think James Gun knows a little more than we do when it comes to what makes a successful movie. Uh, and finally, I do want to talk about Kenvue real quick. They faced push from activist investors for changes on how the company is structured and run ever since it was spun off from J&J just a couple of years ago. It fell for double-digit losses when we ended at the close today after saying that it'll merge with Beckton Dickinson's biosciences and diagnostic solutions business in a reverse Morris Trust transaction that's valued at about 17.5 billion. But if you look at the stock on a year-to-date basis, down about 18%. I know it's Monday, but I did want to talk about an alcohol company. Uh, which of course we know these are key markets for those drink makers. So, tariffs are really the story here. But, uh, this is a 28 billion company. They own Medela, Corona, a lot of the names that we know here. But, shares are down about 26% this year. So, not great news here for the brand. Maybe people are going to healthier alternatives. We'll see.

I like the fact you picked an alcohol company because you really truly are filling Carol Masters.

Have to live up to it the best I can.

Also, Fluence Energy, that's uh, an energy per, uh, this is an energy company, and we saw energy is the worst performing sector in the S&P 500 today, and this was one of the names that was in the red. Missou cut the stock to neutral from outperform. They're also pointing toward this tariff impact and additionally the Republican tax and spending bills effects on the clean energy sector. The company's about $1.4 billion dollars in market cap. But I'm looking at the year-to-date as well, down 50%. Not looking good.

All right, let's get a quick check on yields. Continue to see a steepening of the curve. Treasuries overall falling for a third straight day. That's pushing yields higher, but two interesting dynamics are playing out. One is obviously that you're seeing much greater moves in yields on the longer end of the curve to the upside. But on the short end of the curve, take a look at that. A one basis point move, one and a half if you want to be uh particular on that two-year yield. And that has been the narrow range that we've actually seen on the shorter end of the curve now for quite some time. In fact, the past three sessions, we basically had one basis point, one basis point, and then three basis points. And then if you keep going out, it really doesn't get much wider than that. And I think it is kind of telling, uh, Tim and Nora, this idea, uh, that maybe you have a market, at least in the Treasury market, with a lot of folks right now on the sidelines.

Okay. Well, we'll see what happens when it comes to CPI. We'll see what happens when it comes to the big banks reporting earnings. In the meantime, I want to talk a little bit about return to office. Yeah, we're still talking about that. It's back in the news this week because Starbucks employees who work at corporate headquarters are apparently going to be required to come in four days a week. This is a focus. Excuse me. Which four?

I don't know.

Maybe they get to select the day that they stay home.

Well, I know that there are some places where they're like, "Okay, everybody has to come in at least on like, you know, Monday because that's like our in-office day." And it ser, look, it kind of looks like not a lot of people go to work on Friday. Just anecdotally speaking, at least here in New York Subway. I don't know.

Well, we're all here, right? We're in person. But I think this is really interesting for Starbucks. I mean, I was just at Starbucks yesterday and I had a nice refresher. I don't know if you guys have had the refreshers, but fantastic. And we're really seeing, you know, Starbucks really just trying to do better. They're trying to have a turnaround story here. So, I guess they need people in the office to do it.

Well, it starts with the culture, according to Brian Nickel, who's the CEO of Starbucks. Um, you know, we're keeping an eye, of course, on the tariff story. And even though there's new threats of tariffs, uh, and, uh, companies still aren't able to say very much, there is evidence that it is affecting certain industries. The world's largest swimming pool maker says they will likely hike prices for a second time this year because of Trump's proposed tariffs. This is a Spanish company, Fluidra, uh, talking about this, and they said how much they can't say right now really depends on what gets announced about China in the coming weeks.

Yeah, and this is kind of what I'm really interested in for this particular earning season. The idea as to whether we're going to hear more companies, more certainly more US companies start to talk about the potential impact. We just had Nadia Levelvel on the TV program a little while ago, and she was kind of alluding to this idea that we've collected in this country more than a hundred billion dollars in tariff revenue, but of course we know that comes out of someone's pocket, and at least for right now, we have not actually seen that show up in some of these income statements or in some of the inflation data, and I do wonder if that's about to change.

And that's why the guidance tomorrow and throughout the rest of earning season is going to be so important, the commentary that we hear, although is there more clarity that's, you know, about what the actual policies? At some point, they have to, company executives just need to say how they're moving forward, even if they don't have the clarity. Right.

Absolutely.

Okay. We'll wait.

What kind of swimming pool do you have, Scarlet?

Mine is massive.

All right. Party at Scarlet this weekend. Thanks for the interview.
